Newcastle United would not have been able to sign 9 of their current crop of players, had Britain not been part of the European Union when they arrived in the UK, research has shown. 
Britain has voted to to leave the EU after a country-wide referendum which saw the “Brexit” side win with 52% of votes. 
With the dust having barely settled after the vote, the ramifications are still being worked out, but what is expected is that the ability for anyone from within the EU to come and work in the UK will surely change - and that could include some top football stars. 
A report in The Mirror revealed that 108 Premier League players would not have been able to sign for their respective clubs had Britain not been part of the EU when they arrived here. 
It showed that players who didn’t have the requisite number of competitive international caps would not have been granted an automatic visa to work in the UK and could have been prevented from making their transfers. 
Under current employment rules, any player with an EU passport is free to play in the UK without restriction, while those from outside Europe must meet specific Home Office criteria which depends on how many international appearances they have made and where their country sits in the FIFA rankings. 
What does that mean for Newcastle United? Well, it would have meant the likes of Ayoze Perez, Vurnon Anita and Tim Krul would not have been eligible to sign for the Magpies. 
It also means the likes of Manu Riviere, Gabriel Obertan and Siem de Jong wouldn’t have been eligible either.
